comment-486: Solo developers only work if your marketing skills are top notch. Your product is only as good as how it responds to the market and how it’s presented. If there’s a need or solves a problem people have, or if it helps a person go from their current state and help them achieve their dream state of some kind, or makes their life easier (convenience), then chances are, your service will work. Also nothing is done solo. You’ll do the programming, UX/UI design, QA testing, marketing, negotiating with investors and future buyers, and be responsible with everything. You will easily get burnt out doing it so it’s best to delegate and divide the responsibilities as you can, which is where your outreaching skills happen. That’s why a lot of those tech startups end up succeeding. You needa hold 20 different positions when doing this. Many have tried, only few succeeded and you need to be OBSESSED with your craft to truly be successful in it. Most will choose the software engineering route and work for some tech company making 150k a year with insane growth benefits, but very few are bold and crazy enough to try and go all or nothing. Many fail trying to achieve this dream. It’s not for everyone. Those that are bold, I’m rooting for you. The sky is the limit.

comment-620:
I have worked as a software developer for well over 20 years. I have worked in other people's start ups, in big companies, my own start up, freelance and even in a government agency. Meaning, I have about seen it all.
First and foremost most of what is presented on youtube about working in software is wrong, and intentionally misleading.
Where I made the most money was either in a big company or in a government agency. It is also where I did the least amount of programming. In the start up's of other people is where I did the most amount of programming and very long hours, and made much less money, but ironically had "more fun"(..sort of...) because I was actually programming systems that were "revolutionary" in a sense that they had not been done before.
Working freelance was by far the worse job. Those contracting have unrealistic expectations, and want to pay almost nothing. I would highly recommend staying away from freelance work, unless you are homeless and starving, and even then you will probably make more money per hour as a dishwasher.
Where my views on software development really changed completely is when I had my own start up company. That was like being in a rollercoaster and in a washing machine all at the same time. I got a small team together and we started a company, and I had 2 investors to finance it. Before finishing the project, our investors found us more investors, but these investors want to buy out everything, which would make quick money for the original investors, but turn me into a simple employee with some shares(not an owner of the company). I turned the offer down. The project dragged on, and took about 5 years to finish. After about the first 2 years I had already lost about 80% of the original team, and after 3 years I was the only person left, with 1 investor supporting me, and the 2nd investor plotting how to kill me, since he was angry about how long it was taking, and having super unrealistic expectations that he would become a billionaire in a couple of months.
Nevertheless the project finished after 5 years, which was a software suite for professional televesion stations(competition would be systems like Tricaster,etc.) I sold one copy of the software to a local TV station for $12,000, which was cheap because the competition systems were selling for around $25,000; this was highly specialized software.
I was on a high, as the TV station actually was really happy with the software....but after a few months, they started asking, where is version 2.0?? They said the competition software already had more features, so I promised them a version 2.0 to add more features. But then reality set in. I was the only programmer left in the company, the software was already becoming outdated. It would take a long time get v.2.0 out, and the investors wanted a return on their money. The doubled sided sword, was that this TV station talked to other TV stations, telling them my software was good, but recommending them to wait for v2.0 before buying.
In the end $12,000 for 5 years of nonstop work, and headaches, is sad.
To even make things worse, Free, open source software started coming out, even though bad, was starting to be used by the TV stations to save money, reducing the customer base.
Let's be realistic, nobody pays for software nowadays. Everyone expects everything to be for "free". If someone pays for software it is usually a videogame. And companies that pay for software have their own software development teams to make their own software. And to make it worse there are literraly slave shops in India, and China making software for almost no pay.
The whole story of making some stupid android app and becoming a millionaire is really castles in the sky.
I not sure why this lie is so readily perpetuated on youtube. I think most people would be smarter to believe in Santa Claus or the Tooth fairy.

I actually think the biggest reason why a lot of people are against using firebase tools, is because the functions take you out of the free plan.
when a developer builds his first start-up he doesn't want to pay any money at the start, until he realizes if it's a fail or not.
that's why a lot people are going to Vercel, AWS and more, that's why Heroku was so famous until the recent updates.

a long time ago, I created a SaSS platform which was build on top of firebase, and after the realization of function costing money, we just moved out.
someone needs to talk to the team behind firebase, and let them know that including some functions capabilities in the free plan will greatly increase customers...

comment-875:
The ultimate Firebase Docs query, it can do it all:

export async function query_data(table, get = { "user_uid": ['==', uid] }) {
const processQuery = (query) => {
return ( (query.mode || 'and') === 'and' ? and : or)(
...Object.entries(query).map(([key, value]) => {
if (key === 'mode') return null;
if (Array.isArray(value)) {
return where(key, value[0], value[1]);
} else {
return processQuery(value);
}
}).filter(Boolean)
);
};
return await getDocs(query(collection(fb_db, table), processQuery(get)));
}

❤‍🔥

comment-1107:
The main thing here is, it's dependent on where you live.

If I lived in bumfucknowhere, Japan (where my wife's parents live), I could buy an (albeit old, but livable) house for 20-30000 USD, and then live off of <1000USD a month.

However, in Switzerland, where I live and work now, I have a salary of ~100k for a normal 40 hour work week being a developer, and just sustaining myself with a rented apartment costs me almost 3000 a month.

So, if I lived in the Japanese countryside, selling some app A for 10 bucks, I would only need 100 sales a month and live decently, while here I would need 300 sales a month to just somewhat survive.

comment-1475: Solo developers only work if your marketing skills are top notch. Your product is only as good as how it responds to the market and how it’s presented. If there’s a need or solves a problem people have, or if it helps a person go from their current state and help them achieve their dream state of some kind, or makes their life easier (convenience), then chances are, your service will work. Also nothing is done solo. You’ll do the programming, UX/UI design, QA testing, marketing, negotiating with investors and future buyers, and be responsible with everything. You will easily get burnt out doing it so it’s best to delegate and divide the responsibilities as you can, which is where your outreaching skills happen. That’s why a lot of those tech startups end up succeeding. You needa hold 20 different positions when doing this. Many have tried, only few succeeded and you need to be OBSESSED with your craft to truly be successful in it. Most will choose the software engineering route and work for some tech company making 150k a year with insane growth benefits, but very few are bold and crazy enough to try and go all or nothing. Many fail trying to achieve this dream. It’s not for everyone. Those that are bold, I’m rooting for you. The sky is the limit.

comment-1609:
I have worked as a software developer for well over 20 years. I have worked in other people's start ups, in big companies, my own start up, freelance and even in a government agency. Meaning, I have about seen it all.
First and foremost most of what is presented on youtube about working in software is wrong, and intentionally misleading.
Where I made the most money was either in a big company or in a government agency. It is also where I did the least amount of programming. In the start up's of other people is where I did the most amount of programming and very long hours, and made much less money, but ironically had "more fun"(..sort of...) because I was actually programming systems that were "revolutionary" in a sense that they had not been done before.
Working freelance was by far the worse job. Those contracting have unrealistic expectations, and want to pay almost nothing. I would highly recommend staying away from freelance work, unless you are homeless and starving, and even then you will probably make more money per hour as a dishwasher.
Where my views on software development really changed completely is when I had my own start up company. That was like being in a rollercoaster and in a washing machine all at the same time. I got a small team together and we started a company, and I had 2 investors to finance it. Before finishing the project, our investors found us more investors, but these investors want to buy out everything, which would make quick money for the original investors, but turn me into a simple employee with some shares(not an owner of the company). I turned the offer down. The project dragged on, and took about 5 years to finish. After about the first 2 years I had already lost about 80% of the original team, and after 3 years I was the only person left, with 1 investor supporting me, and the 2nd investor plotting how to kill me, since he was angry about how long it was taking, and having super unrealistic expectations that he would become a billionaire in a couple of months.
Nevertheless the project finished after 5 years, which was a software suite for professional televesion stations(competition would be systems like Tricaster,etc.) I sold one copy of the software to a local TV station for $12,000, which was cheap because the competition systems were selling for around $25,000; this was highly specialized software.
I was on a high, as the TV station actually was really happy with the software....but after a few months, they started asking, where is version 2.0?? They said the competition software already had more features, so I promised them a version 2.0 to add more features. But then reality set in. I was the only programmer left in the company, the software was already becoming outdated. It would take a long time get v.2.0 out, and the investors wanted a return on their money. The doubled sided sword, was that this TV station talked to other TV stations, telling them my software was good, but recommending them to wait for v2.0 before buying.
In the end $12,000 for 5 years of nonstop work, and headaches, is sad.
To even make things worse, Free, open source software started coming out, even though bad, was starting to be used by the TV stations to save money, reducing the customer base.
Let's be realistic, nobody pays for software nowadays. Everyone expects everything to be for "free". If someone pays for software it is usually a videogame. And companies that pay for software have their own software development teams to make their own software. And to make it worse there are literraly slave shops in India, and China making software for almost no pay.
The whole story of making some stupid android app and becoming a millionaire is really castles in the sky.
I not sure why this lie is so readily perpetuated on youtube. I think most people would be smarter to believe in Santa Claus or the Tooth fairy.

I actually think the biggest reason why a lot of people are against using firebase tools, is because the functions take you out of the free plan.
when a developer builds his first start-up he doesn't want to pay any money at the start, until he realizes if it's a fail or not.
that's why a lot people are going to Vercel, AWS and more, that's why Heroku was so famous until the recent updates.

a long time ago, I created a SaSS platform which was build on top of firebase, and after the realization of function costing money, we just moved out.
someone needs to talk to the team behind firebase, and let them know that including some functions capabilities in the free plan will greatly increase customers...

comment-1864:
The ultimate Firebase Docs query, it can do it all:

export async function query_data(table, get = { "user_uid": ['==', uid] }) {
const processQuery = (query) => {
return ( (query.mode || 'and') === 'and' ? and : or)(
...Object.entries(query).map(([key, value]) => {
if (key === 'mode') return null;
if (Array.isArray(value)) {
return where(key, value[0], value[1]);
} else {
return processQuery(value);
}
}).filter(Boolean)
);
};
return await getDocs(query(collection(fb_db, table), processQuery(get)));
}

❤‍🔥

What I'm getting at isn't a general 'why' or 'how' various coded functions work, which I far less oft struggle with. Compared to my pulsating migraine of the 'when' for integrations, back end procedures, etc in many areas. For example, I botch my work by fully overcomplicating what needs to take place in given situations, because of the more constant issues I face of entirely not realizing "wait I must do that there too?/real time knowledge/general back end communications weighed from 'necessarily important' to 'sure but totally unnecessary.' Further, I wish there was a guided searchable roadmap so that I can better flow through these scenarios by best adding the back end nuances across a big bank of examples to study and master. I'm assuming such a tool exists, as I want to spend my time building and making mistakes to overcome, yet not bounce into a cement wall that I paint a rabbit hole on to, without carving that hole through. comment-2096:
The main thing here is, it's dependent on where you live.

If I lived in bumfucknowhere, Japan (where my wife's parents live), I could buy an (albeit old, but livable) house for 20-30000 USD, and then live off of <1000USD a month.

However, in Switzerland, where I live and work now, I have a salary of ~100k for a normal 40 hour work week being a developer, and just sustaining myself with a rented apartment costs me almost 3000 a month.

So, if I lived in the Japanese countryside, selling some app A for 10 bucks, I would only need 100 sales a month and live decently, while here I would need 300 sales a month to just somewhat survive.

comment-2464: Solo developers only work if your marketing skills are top notch. Your product is only as good as how it responds to the market and how it’s presented. If there’s a need or solves a problem people have, or if it helps a person go from their current state and help them achieve their dream state of some kind, or makes their life easier (convenience), then chances are, your service will work. Also nothing is done solo. You’ll do the programming, UX/UI design, QA testing, marketing, negotiating with investors and future buyers, and be responsible with everything. You will easily get burnt out doing it so it’s best to delegate and divide the responsibilities as you can, which is where your outreaching skills happen. That’s why a lot of those tech startups end up succeeding. You needa hold 20 different positions when doing this. Many have tried, only few succeeded and you need to be OBSESSED with your craft to truly be successful in it. Most will choose the software engineering route and work for some tech company making 150k a year with insane growth benefits, but very few are bold and crazy enough to try and go all or nothing. Many fail trying to achieve this dream. It’s not for everyone. Those that are bold, I’m rooting for you. The sky is the limit.

comment-2598:
I have worked as a software developer for well over 20 years. I have worked in other people's start ups, in big companies, my own start up, freelance and even in a government agency. Meaning, I have about seen it all.
First and foremost most of what is presented on youtube about working in software is wrong, and intentionally misleading.
Where I made the most money was either in a big company or in a government agency. It is also where I did the least amount of programming. In the start up's of other people is where I did the most amount of programming and very long hours, and made much less money, but ironically had "more fun"(..sort of...) because I was actually programming systems that were "revolutionary" in a sense that they had not been done before.
Working freelance was by far the worse job. Those contracting have unrealistic expectations, and want to pay almost nothing. I would highly recommend staying away from freelance work, unless you are homeless and starving, and even then you will probably make more money per hour as a dishwasher.
Where my views on software development really changed completely is when I had my own start up company. That was like being in a rollercoaster and in a washing machine all at the same time. I got a small team together and we started a company, and I had 2 investors to finance it. Before finishing the project, our investors found us more investors, but these investors want to buy out everything, which would make quick money for the original investors, but turn me into a simple employee with some shares(not an owner of the company). I turned the offer down. The project dragged on, and took about 5 years to finish. After about the first 2 years I had already lost about 80% of the original team, and after 3 years I was the only person left, with 1 investor supporting me, and the 2nd investor plotting how to kill me, since he was angry about how long it was taking, and having super unrealistic expectations that he would become a billionaire in a couple of months.
Nevertheless the project finished after 5 years, which was a software suite for professional televesion stations(competition would be systems like Tricaster,etc.) I sold one copy of the software to a local TV station for $12,000, which was cheap because the competition systems were selling for around $25,000; this was highly specialized software.
I was on a high, as the TV station actually was really happy with the software....but after a few months, they started asking, where is version 2.0?? They said the competition software already had more features, so I promised them a version 2.0 to add more features. But then reality set in. I was the only programmer left in the company, the software was already becoming outdated. It would take a long time get v.2.0 out, and the investors wanted a return on their money. The doubled sided sword, was that this TV station talked to other TV stations, telling them my software was good, but recommending them to wait for v2.0 before buying.
In the end $12,000 for 5 years of nonstop work, and headaches, is sad.
To even make things worse, Free, open source software started coming out, even though bad, was starting to be used by the TV stations to save money, reducing the customer base.
Let's be realistic, nobody pays for software nowadays. Everyone expects everything to be for "free". If someone pays for software it is usually a videogame. And companies that pay for software have their own software development teams to make their own software. And to make it worse there are literraly slave shops in India, and China making software for almost no pay.
The whole story of making some stupid android app and becoming a millionaire is really castles in the sky.
I not sure why this lie is so readily perpetuated on youtube. I think most people would be smarter to believe in Santa Claus or the Tooth fairy.

that's why a lot people are going to Vercel, AWS and more, that's why Heroku was so famous until the recent updates.

a long time ago, I created a SaSS platform which was build on top of firebase, and after the realization of function costing money, we just moved out.
someone needs to talk to the team behind firebase, and let them know that including some functions capabilities in the free plan will greatly increase customers...

The ultimate Firebase Docs query, it can do it all:

export async function query_data(table, get = { "user_uid": ['==', uid] }) {
const processQuery = (query) => {
return ( (query.mode || 'and') === 'and' ? and : or)(
...Object.entries(query).map(([key, value]) => {
if (key === 'mode') return null;
if (Array.isArray(value)) {
return where(key, value[0], value[1]);
} else {
return processQuery(value);
}
}).filter(Boolean)
);
};
return await getDocs(query(collection(fb_db, table), processQuery(get)));
}

comment-3085:
The main thing here is, it's dependent on where you live.

If I lived in bumfucknowhere, Japan (where my wife's parents live), I could buy an (albeit old, but livable) house for 20-30000 USD, and then live off of <1000USD a month.

However, in Switzerland, where I live and work now, I have a salary of ~100k for a normal 40 hour work week being a developer, and just sustaining myself with a rented apartment costs me almost 3000 a month.

So, if I lived in the Japanese countryside, selling some app A for 10 bucks, I would only need 100 sales a month and live decently, while here I would need 300 sales a month to just somewhat survive.

comment-3453: Solo developers only work if your marketing skills are top notch. Your product is only as good as how it responds to the market and how it’s presented. If there’s a need or solves a problem people have, or if it helps a person go from their current state and help them achieve their dream state of some kind, or makes their life easier (convenience), then chances are, your service will work. Also nothing is done solo. You’ll do the programming, UX/UI design, QA testing, marketing, negotiating with investors and future buyers, and be responsible with everything. You will easily get burnt out doing it so it’s best to delegate and divide the responsibilities as you can, which is where your outreaching skills happen. That’s why a lot of those tech startups end up succeeding. You needa hold 20 different positions when doing this. Many have tried, only few succeeded and you need to be OBSESSED with your craft to truly be successful in it. Most will choose the software engineering route and work for some tech company making 150k a year with insane growth benefits, but very few are bold and crazy enough to try and go all or nothing. Many fail trying to achieve this dream. It’s not for everyone. Those that are bold, I’m rooting for you. The sky is the limit.

comment-3587:
I have worked as a software developer for well over 20 years. I have worked in other people's start ups, in big companies, my own start up, freelance and even in a government agency. Meaning, I have about seen it all.
First and foremost most of what is presented on youtube about working in software is wrong, and intentionally misleading.
Where I made the most money was either in a big company or in a government agency. It is also where I did the least amount of programming. In the start up's of other people is where I did the most amount of programming and very long hours, and made much less money, but ironically had "more fun"(..sort of...) because I was actually programming systems that were "revolutionary" in a sense that they had not been done before.
Working freelance was by far the worse job. Those contracting have unrealistic expectations, and want to pay almost nothing. I would highly recommend staying away from freelance work, unless you are homeless and starving, and even then you will probably make more money per hour as a dishwasher.
Where my views on software development really changed completely is when I had my own start up company. That was like being in a rollercoaster and in a washing machine all at the same time. I got a small team together and we started a company, and I had 2 investors to finance it. Before finishing the project, our investors found us more investors, but these investors want to buy out everything, which would make quick money for the original investors, but turn me into a simple employee with some shares(not an owner of the company). I turned the offer down. The project dragged on, and took about 5 years to finish. After about the first 2 years I had already lost about 80% of the original team, and after 3 years I was the only person left, with 1 investor supporting me, and the 2nd investor plotting how to kill me, since he was angry about how long it was taking, and having super unrealistic expectations that he would become a billionaire in a couple of months.
Nevertheless the project finished after 5 years, which was a software suite for professional televesion stations(competition would be systems like Tricaster,etc.) I sold one copy of the software to a local TV station for $12,000, which was cheap because the competition systems were selling for around $25,000; this was highly specialized software.
I was on a high, as the TV station actually was really happy with the software....but after a few months, they started asking, where is version 2.0?? They said the competition software already had more features, so I promised them a version 2.0 to add more features. But then reality set in. I was the only programmer left in the company, the software was already becoming outdated. It would take a long time get v.2.0 out, and the investors wanted a return on their money. The doubled sided sword, was that this TV station talked to other TV stations, telling them my software was good, but recommending them to wait for v2.0 before buying.
In the end $12,000 for 5 years of nonstop work, and headaches, is sad.
To even make things worse, Free, open source software started coming out, even though bad, was starting to be used by the TV stations to save money, reducing the customer base.
Let's be realistic, nobody pays for software nowadays. Everyone expects everything to be for "free". If someone pays for software it is usually a videogame. And companies that pay for software have their own software development teams to make their own software. And to make it worse there are literraly slave shops in India, and China making software for almost no pay.
The whole story of making some stupid android app and becoming a millionaire is really castles in the sky.
I not sure why this lie is so readily perpetuated on youtube. I think most people would be smarter to believe in Santa Claus or the Tooth fairy.

The ultimate Firebase Docs query, it can do it all:

export async function query_data(table, get = { "user_uid": ['==', uid] }) {
const processQuery = (query) => {
return ( (query.mode || 'and') === 'and' ? and : or)(
...Object.entries(query).map(([key, value]) => {
if (key === 'mode') return null;
if (Array.isArray(value)) {
return where(key, value[0], value[1]);
} else {
return processQuery(value);
}
}).filter(Boolean)
);
};
return await getDocs(query(collection(fb_db, table), processQuery(get)));
}

comment-4074:
The main thing here is, it's dependent on where you live.

If I lived in bumfucknowhere, Japan (where my wife's parents live), I could buy an (albeit old, but livable) house for 20-30000 USD, and then live off of <1000USD a month.

However, in Switzerland, where I live and work now, I have a salary of ~100k for a normal 40 hour work week being a developer, and just sustaining myself with a rented apartment costs me almost 3000 a month.

So, if I lived in the Japanese countryside, selling some app A for 10 bucks, I would only need 100 sales a month and live decently, while here I would need 300 sales a month to just somewhat survive.

comment-5818:
Please stand by. You are under review.

- The opening poses are magnificent
- The lighting is impeccable
- Love the transition in Ballora's mouth
- I appreciate the more possessed and unnatural movement of Bonnie
- I like how Springtrap moves so much more human-like, very neat
- The minireenas spell BABY, that is such a cool detail
- Elizabeth's death, from the dust to the animation, the lighting, everything is beautiful
- Purple smiling camera is the cutest FNAF character, but also a very cool detail with the dots forming said smile
- I don't like that Funtime Foxy model, but it's passable
- While I don't like the Funtime Foxy model, the scene with the flashing lights and FFx swaying back and forth as he makes his way over is pretty terrifying
- Ennard's animation is so fluid and smooth, I love it, masterfully done
- Pretty sure that's Sebastian from the The Evil Within franchise, but it's better than Rick Astley

Final Verdict: I absolutely ADORE this animation and song. It's just so well done and you can tell a huge amount of effort and time was put into this. I'm doing my best to ignore any bias caused by nostalgia. Anyway, I just can't express how happy seeing and listening to this made me.

9.75/10

The person who wrote the song obviously doesn't understand the lore. "Somebody purple murdered me" actually Elizabeth was not intentionally murdered, William her father told her not to go near baby, So if anything she should be mad at herself for not listening to her father. Also William wasn't actually purple, it's been explained by Scott multiple times the in the mini games the only reason that William appears is purple is so he would stand out as a character in the shadows but would be visible.
It's really great how a song that apparently the community sees as such a great thing has absolutely no concept of the continuity in the lore of the actual story.

comment-7339:
I never played Fnaf- honestly I didn't know it was a thing almost until i hit high school- but when i was a kid one of my friends somehow found this song, and although we only knew the start of the chorus and had no clue where it came from (to this day i wonder where she found it without realising Fnaf existed) but we loved it. It may just be part of the reason we're still friends today. This song carries so much meaning even for a kid like me who never knew about its origins. Which i think really shows how amazing it is- the beat and the lyrics are so easy to remember and so catchy that it's a great song to sing together with friends, regardless of if you're a fnaf fan or not. so thanks, JT. Thanks a lot.

On a side note, i really really want to cosplay Ballora. But i feel like that would be betraying the actual fnaf community lol😂 she's just so pretty

comment-8530:
I actually have a long story with this song.

Back at 2017 when I found your channel I loved your raps and didn't understood why this song gone SO viral.
I deeply respect the job Harry101UK has done in creating these visuals - makes me wonder how many kids became robotics enthusiasts because of Scott designs and reimaginations SFM creators did over the years.
I love how emotional this song is and how it swaps between talking to in-game protagonist and you, fan of this series. Listening to it now feels like viewing shard of childhood memories and though I wasn't here back when original released - I am here now and... I adore it.

...that said, the line at 1:52 keeps bothering me. I know original song released before game came out and it was fine to assume that, but now, when we know story of the game, and the REMASTERED version of the track doesn't change or rethought this line... It just makes me sad knowing that this near perfect song and animation would keep such an obvious miss that probably won't be changed forever.

you know, i never expected to start crying to a fnaf song. and yet here we are.
i found out about five nights at freddy’s when i was in kindergarten, six years ago. and when i first heard this song i absolutely adored it. i loved the animation, the vocals, the lyrics, and the somewhat strange relatability of the song. i got bullied a lot through elementary school and fnaf was just kind of my coping mechanism, and your fnaf raps were always the highlights of my day.
i’m now just starting eighth grade, i’m four weeks in now and let me tell you, shit has been rough. high school is only a year away from now and fnaf is still here, thriving and creating amazing content after all of these years. it makes me so happy that one of my favorite all time fnaf songs by my favorite creators has now been redone and even better than before.
thank you so much jt, and of course to andrea once again for her divine vocals on this song. i hope you all realize just how amazing of an impact you’ve created on this community
<333

comment-9439:
So much memories, like holy crap. Sister location was the year me and one of my close cousins spent so much time together so when we saw the sister location trailer we were hyped and waiting on the music videos and teasers. A few months later I think was when "join us for a bite" released and it was one of my favorites so this remake makes me so happy.

Edit: I forgot to include a few gripes soooo.....


1:32 I felt that there was something off with Baby's Shutting off animation. 1:34 Balora's dance felt too fluid as it would make more sense for it to be more finicky like an animatronic. 2:06 I felt that the Animatronics jaws didn't move enough and didn't hit as much as the originals. 2:16 Same thing like Balora it felt too fluid and human like which crossed the uncanny valley for me but that doesn't mean I hate the fluidness entirely, some scenes look stunning like when the face-plates moved and this particular scene at 2:47 which I very much like. 3:00 Idk but Baby's model is a bit off I think its that the head isn't lower down.

Overall the Music is an overall improvement, outstanding lighting that reminds me of "Special Delivery", and TOP notch attention to detail!

comment-9792:
Here is my overall musical analysis of the remaster of Join Us For A Bite, since I think it needs a comparison to the original 2016 version (please also bare in mind that THIS IS MY OPINION);

Pros:
- A lot more depth in the instrumental elements to the song
- Less compression/distortion in the drums and the bass
- Acoustic guitar strums are easier to hear
- Improved 3D sound
- The highs end sounds of the song feel more punchy and clear

Cons:
- A bit too much distortion and autotune in the voiceover (the 2016 version had this as well, though I believe it was at a lower amount of autotune, which helped it sink in with the song)
- The low end sounds don’t feel as deep as they originally did in the 2016 version
- Drums are probably a bit far on the high end of the sound of the songs
- Some of the synth instrumental notes/chords don’t feel as drawn out (probably because they are either compressed or filtered)
- (Personal Recommendation) It would be interesting for the electric guitar appear more often in the instrumental

However, the visuals to the music video of the remaster are definitely an improvement and the production quality of the animation shows the evolution in the FNAF SFM’s compared to the older animations between 2015-2018. So thumbs up the people that helped out with the animation. But also a thumbs up to the JT Music crew for giving one of the most essential ever created FNAF songs new life.

comment-10003:
This song has impacted my life in such a huge way.

I met my best friend, a few months after this song came out, in music class. I was sitting next to her whenever I heard her silently reciting/singing the lyrics to a song. She said "-and Freddy told us your an organ donor." I remember asking her what she was singing, and she told me that I wouldn't know it; she told me, a bit afterwards, that it was a Five Nights At Freddy's song. I began to freak out, explaining to her that I LOVED FNAF. Ever since then, we've been the best of friends. Whenever she moved out-of-state (I still talk to her, though it's not as often as I'd like) I changed her ring-tone to Join Us For A Bite.

The fact that this song was remastered, and that the remastered-version sounds awesome (with great animations) really does mean a lot to me. Thank you for presenting the opportunity of friendship; I didn't have many friends back then, and I was given the best one. <3
comment-10004: This song made me cry because I remember being so happy when the original one came out, I was 9 or 10 at the time and I had showed it to my dad. Since then, he has passed away and getting to listen to this with his necklace around my neck made me cry. Thank you so much for everything and getting to make memories for me and the entire FNAF community ❤️

I remember how hyped I was about the release for this game, knowing it would be one of the first with actual in-game narrative, a stranger atmosphere, and more interactive puzzles. As much as I hate to admit it, my fursona seen in my PFP here was born from the FNAF era of furries as well, and I'd be lying if I said this game didn't have any impact on my own creative works. I might just learn 3D modelling so I can make some that actually make a modicum of sense.

comment-11319: It’s crazy, knowing that I’ve been in this fandom for so long. I’m not sure if you could even consider me being in the fandom for a good three years.  I used to hate Fnaf mostly because I was a dumb six-year-old, who thought it was spooky. I remember my first introduction to Fnaf was actually a CookieSwirlC video. But I’m pretty sure you were the first reason why I ever gave a chance at liking Fnaf, because it was this song. I had this song stuck in my head for weeks. I remember literally going downstairs on Christmas Eve to peek my presents, and realizing that I had this song stuck in my head, telling myself not to like it, because it’s a Fnaf song, and I hate Fnaf, cuz it’s scary. Then I watched a game theory video about Fnaf VR. It took me a couple more months after that but after that I was sold on the fandom and I joined. Thank you so much, JT. If you would never made join us for a bite in the first place, I would’ve never been a part of this amazing fandom. And thank you all for reading through this.❤

comment-11427: Over the many years I've watched this channel I've seen it evolve into something that is a staple when you look into the nerdcore genre. It doesn't even have Skull's vocals but it still feels so iconic for what Skull and Pat have both worked on over the years, Andrea just becoming like a staple unit in songs being released. Sometimes I'll load up a playlist with the original FNAF raps that Skull did for each game in the golden age of the channel. Thank you guys for making my childhood, and just to know you guys are based in North Carolina makes me even happier to have it be my home state. You guys have done so much for the nerdy kids in middle school who were able to bond over nerdcore.

comment-11783:
Obviously I had to comment. This song holds so many memories for me that when I watched the live, I couldn't help but tear up. I have been around the game since the demo and I remember my cousin coming over, telling me about this "scary horror Chuckie Cheese game" that just released a demo, and we played it on their laptop. That same cousin got me into Undertale when its demo came out. Those years started so much for me. 2013 and 2014 were really something. I always kept up with the FNAF games, and when Sister Location came out in 2016, I found my absolute favorite in the series. This song, that game, this community. It all has done something amazing for me that I can never give back enough in return. This song, is my childhood. This song, brought me joy in a way that cannot be described.
You truly realize how much time has passed, when you look back at the dates.. the times. The memories you have feel timeless, and it's not until you look at the written date of some things, that you actually realize... That you are older. You have grown up. That this, has been beside you throughout that time. That those times where you would talk about one kid being an absolute master at gaming simply for beating FNAF's 5th or 6th nights, are in the past...

Thank you JT Music and friends... This is something... that can never be forgotten. <3 <3 <3

comment-13224:
Please stand by. You are under review.

- The opening poses are magnificent
- The lighting is impeccable
- Love the transition in Ballora's mouth
- I appreciate the more possessed and unnatural movement of Bonnie
- I like how Springtrap moves so much more human-like, very neat
- The minireenas spell BABY, that is such a cool detail
- Elizabeth's death, from the dust to the animation, the lighting, everything is beautiful
- Purple smiling camera is the cutest FNAF character, but also a very cool detail with the dots forming said smile
- I don't like that Funtime Foxy model, but it's passable
- While I don't like the Funtime Foxy model, the scene with the flashing lights and FFx swaying back and forth as he makes his way over is pretty terrifying
- Ennard's animation is so fluid and smooth, I love it, masterfully done
- Pretty sure that's Sebastian from the The Evil Within franchise, but it's better than Rick Astley

Final Verdict: I absolutely ADORE this animation and song. It's just so well done and you can tell a huge amount of effort and time was put into this. I'm doing my best to ignore any bias caused by nostalgia. Anyway, I just can't express how happy seeing and listening to this made me.

9.75/10

The person who wrote the song obviously doesn't understand the lore. "Somebody purple murdered me" actually Elizabeth was not intentionally murdered, William her father told her not to go near baby, So if anything she should be mad at herself for not listening to her father. Also William wasn't actually purple, it's been explained by Scott multiple times the in the mini games the only reason that William appears is purple is so he would stand out as a character in the shadows but would be visible.

I never played Fnaf- honestly I didn't know it was a thing almost until i hit high school- but when i was a kid one of my friends somehow found this song, and although we only knew the start of the chorus and had no clue where it came from (to this day i wonder where she found it without realising Fnaf existed) but we loved it. Which i think really shows how amazing it is- the beat and the lyrics are so easy to remember and so catchy that it's a great song to sing together with friends, regardless of if you're a fnaf fan or not. so thanks, JT. Thanks a lot.

On a side note, i really really want to cosplay Ballora. But i feel like that would be betraying the actual fnaf community lol😂 she's just so pretty

comment-15936:
I actually have a long story with this song.

Back at 2017 when I found your channel I loved your raps and didn't understood why this song gone SO viral.
I deeply respect the job Harry101UK has done in creating these visuals - makes me wonder how many kids became robotics enthusiasts because of Scott designs and reimaginations SFM creators did over the years.
I love how emotional this song is and how it swaps between talking to in-game protagonist and you, fan of this series. Listening to it now feels like viewing shard of childhood memories and though I wasn't here back when original released - I am here now and... I adore it.

...that said, the line at 1:52 keeps bothering me. I know original song released before game came out and it was fine to assume that, but now, when we know story of the game, and the REMASTERED version of the track doesn't change or rethought this line... It just makes me sad knowing that this near perfect song and animation would keep such an obvious miss that probably won't be changed forever.

you know, i never expected to start crying to a fnaf song. and yet here we are.
i found out about five nights at freddy’s when i was in kindergarten, six years ago. and when i first heard this song i absolutely adored it. i loved the animation, the vocals, the lyrics, and the somewhat strange relatability of the song. i got bullied a lot through elementary school and fnaf was just kind of my coping mechanism, and your fnaf raps were always the highlights of my day.
i’m now just starting eighth grade, i’m four weeks in now and let me tell you, shit has been rough. high school is only a year away from now and fnaf is still here, thriving and creating amazing content after all of these years. it makes me so happy that one of my favorite all time fnaf songs by my favorite creators has now been redone and even better than before.
thank you so much jt, and of course to andrea once again for her divine vocals on this song. i hope you all realize just how amazing of an impact you’ve created on this community

comment-16845:
So much memories, like holy crap. Sister location was the year me and one of my close cousins spent so much time together so when we saw the sister location trailer we were hyped and waiting on the music videos and teasers. A few months later I think was when "join us for a bite" released and it was one of my favorites so this remake makes me so happy.

Edit: I forgot to include a few gripes soooo.....


1:32 I felt that there was something off with Baby's Shutting off animation. 1:34 Balora's dance felt too fluid as it would make more sense for it to be more finicky like an animatronic. 2:06 I felt that the Animatronics jaws didn't move enough and didn't hit as much as the originals. 2:16 Same thing like Balora it felt too fluid and human like which crossed the uncanny valley for me but that doesn't mean I hate the fluidness entirely, some scenes look stunning like when the face-plates moved and this particular scene at 2:47 which I very much like. 3:00 Idk but Baby's model is a bit off I think its that the head isn't lower down.

Overall the Music is an overall improvement, outstanding lighting that reminds me of "Special Delivery", and TOP notch attention to detail!

comment-17198:
Here is my overall musical analysis of the remaster of Join Us For A Bite, since I think it needs a comparison to the original 2016 version (please also bare in mind that THIS IS MY OPINION);

Pros:
- A lot more depth in the instrumental elements to the song
- Less compression/distortion in the drums and the bass
- Acoustic guitar strums are easier to hear
- Improved 3D sound
- The highs end sounds of the song feel more punchy and clear

Cons:
- A bit too much distortion and autotune in the voiceover (the 2016 version had this as well, though I believe it was at a lower amount of autotune, which helped it sink in with the song)
- The low end sounds don’t feel as deep as they originally did in the 2016 version
- Drums are probably a bit far on the high end of the sound of the songs
- Some of the synth instrumental notes/chords don’t feel as drawn out (probably because they are either compressed or filtered)
- (Personal Recommendation) It would be interesting for the electric guitar appear more often in the instrumental

However, the visuals to the music video of the remaster are definitely an improvement and the production quality of the animation shows the evolution in the FNAF SFM’s compared to the older animations between 2015-2018. So thumbs up the people that helped out with the animation. But also a thumbs up to the JT Music crew for giving one of the most essential ever created FNAF songs new life.

comment-17409:
This song has impacted my life in such a huge way.

I met my best friend, a few months after this song came out, in music class. I was sitting next to her whenever I heard her silently reciting/singing the lyrics to a song. She said "-and Freddy told us your an organ donor." I remember asking her what she was singing, and she told me that I wouldn't know it; she told me, a bit afterwards, that it was a Five Nights At Freddy's song. I began to freak out, explaining to her that I LOVED FNAF. Ever since then, we've been the best of friends. Whenever she moved out-of-state (I still talk to her, though it's not as often as I'd like) I changed her ring-tone to Join Us For A Bite.

The fact that this song was remastered, and that the remastered-version sounds awesome (with great animations) really does mean a lot to me. Thank you for presenting the opportunity of friendship; I didn't have many friends back then, and I was given the best one. <3

Thank you so much for everything and getting to make memories for me and the entire FNAF community ❤️

comment-18725: It’s crazy, knowing that I’ve been in this fandom for so long. I’m not sure if you could even consider me being in the fandom for a good three years.  I used to hate Fnaf mostly because I was a dumb six-year-old, who thought it was spooky. I remember my first introduction to Fnaf was actually a CookieSwirlC video. But I’m pretty sure you were the first reason why I ever gave a chance at liking Fnaf, because it was this song. I had this song stuck in my head for weeks. I remember literally going downstairs on Christmas Eve to peek my presents, and realizing that I had this song stuck in my head, telling myself not to like it, because it’s a Fnaf song, and I hate Fnaf, cuz it’s scary. Then I watched a game theory video about Fnaf VR. It took me a couple more months after that but after that I was sold on the fandom and I joined. Thank you so much, JT. If you would never made join us for a bite in the first place, I would’ve never been a part of this amazing fandom. And thank you all for reading through this.❤

comment-18833: Over the many years I've watched this channel I've seen it evolve into something that is a staple when you look into the nerdcore genre. The video mixed with the new mixing and Andrea's vocals still remaining true to the original video just adds a whole new layer of what "Join Us For A Bite" did for the brand. It doesn't even have Skull's vocals but it still feels so iconic for what Skull and Pat have both worked on over the years, Andrea just becoming like a staple unit in songs being released. Sometimes I'll load up a playlist with the original FNAF raps that Skull did for each game in the golden age of the channel. Thank you guys for making my childhood, and just to know you guys are based in North Carolina makes me even happier to have it be my home state. You guys have done so much for the nerdy kids in middle school who were able to bond over nerdcore.

comment-19189:
Obviously I had to comment. This song holds so many memories for me that when I watched the live, I couldn't help but tear up. I have been around the game since the demo and I remember my cousin coming over, telling me about this "scary horror Chuckie Cheese game" that just released a demo, and we played it on their laptop. That same cousin got me into Undertale when its demo came out. Those years started so much for me. 2013 and 2014 were really something. I always kept up with the FNAF games, and when Sister Location came out in 2016, I found my absolute favorite in the series. This song, that game, this community. It all has done something amazing for me that I can never give back enough in return. This song, is my childhood. This song, brought me joy in a way that cannot be described.
You truly realize how much time has passed, when you look back at the dates.. the times. The memories you have feel timeless, and it's not until you look at the written date of some things, that you actually realize... That you are older. You have grown up. That this, has been beside you throughout that time. That those times where you would talk about one kid being an absolute master at gaming simply for beating FNAF's 5th or 6th nights, are in the past...

Thank you JT Music and friends... This is something... that can never be forgotten. <3 <3 <3
comment-19191: Literally speechless, years later through thick and thin this community has been since the Sister Location days. Thank you for this, this was amazing and everyone on board should be BEYOND proud of themselves!

comment-20630:
Please stand by. You are under review.

- The opening poses are magnificent
- The lighting is impeccable
- Love the transition in Ballora's mouth
- I appreciate the more possessed and unnatural movement of Bonnie
- I like how Springtrap moves so much more human-like, very neat
- The minireenas spell BABY, that is such a cool detail
- Elizabeth's death, from the dust to the animation, the lighting, everything is beautiful
- Purple smiling camera is the cutest FNAF character, but also a very cool detail with the dots forming said smile
- I don't like that Funtime Foxy model, but it's passable
- While I don't like the Funtime Foxy model, the scene with the flashing lights and FFx swaying back and forth as he makes his way over is pretty terrifying
- Ennard's animation is so fluid and smooth, I love it, masterfully done
- Pretty sure that's Sebastian from the The Evil Within franchise, but it's better than Rick Astley

Final Verdict: I absolutely ADORE this animation and song. It's just so well done and you can tell a huge amount of effort and time was put into this. I'm doing my best to ignore any bias caused by nostalgia. Anyway, I just can't express how happy seeing and listening to this made me.

9.75/10

comment-21674:
The person who wrote the song obviously doesn't understand the lore. "Somebody purple murdered me" actually Elizabeth was not intentionally murdered, William her father told her not to go near baby, So if anything she should be mad at herself for not listening to her father. Also William wasn't actually purple, it's been explained by Scott multiple times the in the mini games the only reason that William appears is purple is so he would stand out as a character in the shadows but would be visible.
It's really great how a song that apparently the community sees as such a great thing has absolutely no concept of the continuity in the lore of the actual story.
comment-21675: The fact that the person giving the direction in this video made baby's eyes green while she's grabbing Elizabeth has absolutely no concept of this series. Even someone new to the series knows that baby's eyes were blue before grabbing Elizabeth. All of this time and effort put into this animation and the person that gave the direction to the animator couldn't bother telling them the eye color difference. It's absolutely depressing the lack of detail in this video that everyone apparently is praising as if it was handmade by God.

I never played Fnaf- honestly I didn't know it was a thing almost until i hit high school- but when i was a kid one of my friends somehow found this song, and although we only knew the start of the chorus and had no clue where it came from (to this day i wonder where she found it without realising Fnaf existed) but we loved it. It may just be part of the reason we're still friends today. This song carries so much meaning even for a kid like me who never knew about its origins. Which i think really shows how amazing it is- the beat and the lyrics are so easy to remember and so catchy that it's a great song to sing together with friends, regardless of if you're a fnaf fan or not. so thanks, JT. Thanks a lot.

On a side note, i really really want to cosplay Ballora. But i feel like that would be betraying the actual fnaf community lol😂 she's just so pretty

comment-23342:
I actually have a long story with this song.

Back at 2017 when I found your channel I loved your raps and didn't understood why this song gone SO viral.
I deeply respect the job Harry101UK has done in creating these visuals - makes me wonder how many kids became robotics enthusiasts because of Scott designs and reimaginations SFM creators did over the years.
I love how emotional this song is and how it swaps between talking to in-game protagonist and you, fan of this series. Listening to it now feels like viewing shard of childhood memories and though I wasn't here back when original released - I am here now and... I adore it.

...that said, the line at 1:52 keeps bothering me. I know original song released before game came out and it was fine to assume that, but now, when we know story of the game, and the REMASTERED version of the track doesn't change or rethought this line... It just makes me sad knowing that this near perfect song and animation would keep such an obvious miss that probably won't be changed forever.

comment-23444:
you know, i never expected to start crying to a fnaf song. and yet here we are.
i found out about five nights at freddy’s when i was in kindergarten, six years ago. and when i first heard this song i absolutely adored it. i loved the animation, the vocals, the lyrics, and the somewhat strange relatability of the song. i got bullied a lot through elementary school and fnaf was just kind of my coping mechanism, and your fnaf raps were always the highlights of my day.
i’m now just starting eighth grade, i’m four weeks in now and let me tell you, shit has been rough. high school is only a year away from now and fnaf is still here, thriving and creating amazing content after all of these years. it makes me so happy that one of my favorite all time fnaf songs by my favorite creators has now been redone and even better than before.
thank you so much jt, and of course to andrea once again for her divine vocals on this song. i hope you all realize just how amazing of an impact you’ve created on this community
<333

comment-24251:
So much memories, like holy crap. Sister location was the year me and one of my close cousins spent so much time together so when we saw the sister location trailer we were hyped and waiting on the music videos and teasers. A few months later I think was when "join us for a bite" released and it was one of my favorites so this remake makes me so happy.

Edit: I forgot to include a few gripes soooo.....


1:32 I felt that there was something off with Baby's Shutting off animation. 1:34 Balora's dance felt too fluid as it would make more sense for it to be more finicky like an animatronic. 2:06 I felt that the Animatronics jaws didn't move enough and didn't hit as much as the originals. 2:16 Same thing like Balora it felt too fluid and human like which crossed the uncanny valley for me but that doesn't mean I hate the fluidness entirely, some scenes look stunning like when the face-plates moved and this particular scene at 2:47 which I very much like. 3:00 Idk but Baby's model is a bit off I think its that the head isn't lower down.

Overall the Music is an overall improvement, outstanding lighting that reminds me of "Special Delivery", and TOP notch attention to detail!

comment-24604:
Here is my overall musical analysis of the remaster of Join Us For A Bite, since I think it needs a comparison to the original 2016 version (please also bare in mind that THIS IS MY OPINION);

Pros:
- A lot more depth in the instrumental elements to the song
- Less compression/distortion in the drums and the bass
- Acoustic guitar strums are easier to hear
- Improved 3D sound
- The highs end sounds of the song feel more punchy and clear

Cons:
- A bit too much distortion and autotune in the voiceover (the 2016 version had this as well, though I believe it was at a lower amount of autotune, which helped it sink in with the song)
- The low end sounds don’t feel as deep as they originally did in the 2016 version
- Drums are probably a bit far on the high end of the sound of the songs
- Some of the synth instrumental notes/chords don’t feel as drawn out (probably because they are either compressed or filtered)
- (Personal Recommendation) It would be interesting for the electric guitar appear more often in the instrumental

However, the visuals to the music video of the remaster are definitely an improvement and the production quality of the animation shows the evolution in the FNAF SFM’s compared to the older animations between 2015-2018. So thumbs up the people that helped out with the animation. But also a thumbs up to the JT Music crew for giving one of the most essential ever created FNAF songs new life.

comment-24815:
This song has impacted my life in such a huge way.

I met my best friend, a few months after this song came out, in music class. I was sitting next to her whenever I heard her silently reciting/singing the lyrics to a song. She said "-and Freddy told us your an organ donor." I remember asking her what she was singing, and she told me that I wouldn't know it; she told me, a bit afterwards, that it was a Five Nights At Freddy's song. I began to freak out, explaining to her that I LOVED FNAF. Ever since then, we've been the best of friends. Whenever she moved out-of-state (I still talk to her, though it's not as often as I'd like) I changed her ring-tone to Join Us For A Bite.

The fact that this song was remastered, and that the remastered-version sounds awesome (with great animations) really does mean a lot to me. Thank you for presenting the opportunity of friendship; I didn't have many friends back then, and I was given the best one. <3
comment-24816: This song made me cry because I remember being so happy when the original one came out, I was 9 or 10 at the time and I had showed it to my dad. Since then, he has passed away and getting to listen to this with his necklace around my neck made me cry. Thank you so much for everything and getting to make memories for me and the entire FNAF community ❤️

comment-26131: It’s crazy, knowing that I’ve been in this fandom for so long. I’m not sure if you could even consider me being in the fandom for a good three years.  I used to hate Fnaf mostly because I was a dumb six-year-old, who thought it was spooky. I remember my first introduction to Fnaf was actually a CookieSwirlC video. But I’m pretty sure you were the first reason why I ever gave a chance at liking Fnaf, because it was this song. I had this song stuck in my head for weeks. I remember literally going downstairs on Christmas Eve to peek my presents, and realizing that I had this song stuck in my head, telling myself not to like it, because it’s a Fnaf song, and I hate Fnaf, cuz it’s scary. Then I watched a game theory video about Fnaf VR. It took me a couple more months after that but after that I was sold on the fandom and I joined. Thank you so much, JT. If you would never made join us for a bite in the first place, I would’ve never been a part of this amazing fandom. And thank you all for reading through this.❤

comment-26239: Over the many years I've watched this channel I've seen it evolve into something that is a staple when you look into the nerdcore genre. The video mixed with the new mixing and Andrea's vocals still remaining true to the original video just adds a whole new layer of what "Join Us For A Bite" did for the brand. It doesn't even have Skull's vocals but it still feels so iconic for what Skull and Pat have both worked on over the years, Andrea just becoming like a staple unit in songs being released. Sometimes I'll load up a playlist with the original FNAF raps that Skull did for each game in the golden age of the channel. Thank you guys for making my childhood, and just to know you guys are based in North Carolina makes me even happier to have it be my home state. You guys have done so much for the nerdy kids in middle school who were able to bond over nerdcore.

comment-26595:
Obviously I had to comment. This song holds so many memories for me that when I watched the live, I couldn't help but tear up. I have been around the game since the demo and I remember my cousin coming over, telling me about this "scary horror Chuckie Cheese game" that just released a demo, and we played it on their laptop. That same cousin got me into Undertale when its demo came out. Those years started so much for me. 2013 and 2014 were really something. I always kept up with the FNAF games, and when Sister Location came out in 2016, I found my absolute favorite in the series. This song, that game, this community. It all has done something amazing for me that I can never give back enough in return. This song, is my childhood. This song, brought me joy in a way that cannot be described.
You truly realize how much time has passed, when you look back at the dates.. the times. The memories you have feel timeless, and it's not until you look at the written date of some things, that you actually realize... That you are older. You have grown up. That this, has been beside you throughout that time. That those times where you would talk about one kid being an absolute master at gaming simply for beating FNAF's 5th or 6th nights, are in the past...

Thank you JT Music and friends... This is something... that can never be forgotten. <3 <3 <3
comment-26597: Literally speechless, years later through thick and thin this community has been since the Sister Location days. Sends literal chills down my spine, the animation is so top notch, I mean it's Harry101UK of course it's going to be good. But the remaster, holy fucking shit JT, you and Andrea have always and always will be such an iconic duo. Thank you for this, this was amazing and everyone on board should be BEYOND proud of themselves!

When trying to run the dataset_generator for the first time, about 54:30 in the video, it throws an "unexpected token in JSON at position 0" (two spaces after 'token" implying a null/undefined value there). figured I'd share this in case, 1) someone else has worked through it, and 2) you might not have received much feedback from mac users if your students are a PC clan.

In any event, I'll eventually debug this, I'm just so thankful for you and this content. Please keep up the good work.

comment-27314:
I was following allong with the Javascript segment and ran into a problem where even after "this.paths" was consistent throughout the sketchpad, there was a problem with 'this.paths.push' still not being defined. As it turned out, it was chicken and egg problem with the array definition not have a valid array entry value, and thus being considered empty, and therefore, undefined. I was able to resolve this issue this this code:

<<< #addEventListeners(){
this.canvas.onmousedown = (evt) => {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath = [mouse]; // Start a new path with the starting point
this.isDrawing = true;
};

this.canvas.onmousemove = (evt) => {
if (this.isDrawing) {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath.push(mouse); // Add points to the current path
this.#redraw();
}
};

this.canvas.onmouseup = () => {
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
this.paths.push(this.currentPath); // Save the completed path
}
this.currentPath = null; // Reset the current path
this.isDrawing = false;
};
}


#redraw(){
this.ctx.clearRect(0, 0, this.canvas.width, this.canvas.height);
draw.paths(this.ctx, this.paths);
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
draw.path(this.ctx, this.currentPath); // Draw the currently active path
}
}>>>

comment-27335:
It happened to me that when I touched the screen and dragged my finger, the whole screen and the canvas were dragged together (28 min.).

I saw that this is the default behavior. So I just added a "preventDefault();" to functions associated with events.

Code:
this.canvas.ontouchstart = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousedown(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchmove = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousemove(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchend = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
this.canvas.onmouseup();
}

comment-27359:
Just as a quick aside in the beginning part, if you set the content type to "text/plain" in the data string, you may run into issues when downloading file data because the browser thinks it should be a .txt file. If you instead set the content type to be "application/json", it will download just fine without a warning. Like so: "data:application/json;charset=utf-8"

Chrome warned me on MacOS whenever I wanted to download this file with a .json extension that had a content type of text/plain.
comment-27360:
Hi Radu, I just finished the first part of the course. Great so far, thank you. You asked if there was a better way to handle the download anchor click. I'd like to suggest the following:

const element = document.createElement("a");
element.setAttribute(
"href",
"data:text/plain;charset=utf-8," +
encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(data))
);

const fileName = data.session + ".json";
element.setAttribute("download", fileName);
element.click();

There shouldn't be any need to actually inject the anchor into the document. You can simply create the element and invoke the click directly in memory. Hope this helps :)

comment-27572:
I was following allong with the Javascript segment and ran into a problem where even after "this.paths" was consistent throughout the sketchpad, there was a problem with 'this.paths.push' still not being defined. As it turned out, it was chicken and egg problem with the array definition not have a valid array entry value, and thus being considered empty, and therefore, undefined. I was able to resolve this issue this this code:

<<< #addEventListeners(){
this.canvas.onmousedown = (evt) => {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath = [mouse]; // Start a new path with the starting point
this.isDrawing = true;
};

this.canvas.onmousemove = (evt) => {
if (this.isDrawing) {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath.push(mouse); // Add points to the current path
this.#redraw();
}
};

this.canvas.onmouseup = () => {
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
this.paths.push(this.currentPath); // Save the completed path
}
this.currentPath = null; // Reset the current path
this.isDrawing = false;
};
}


#redraw(){
this.ctx.clearRect(0, 0, this.canvas.width, this.canvas.height);
draw.paths(this.ctx, this.paths);
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
draw.path(this.ctx, this.currentPath); // Draw the currently active path
}
}>>>

comment-27593:
It happened to me that when I touched the screen and dragged my finger, the whole screen and the canvas were dragged together (28 min.).

I saw that this is the default behavior. So I just added a "preventDefault();" to functions associated with events.

Code:
this.canvas.ontouchstart = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousedown(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchmove = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousemove(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchend = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
this.canvas.onmouseup();
}

Just as a quick aside in the beginning part, if you set the content type to "text/plain" in the data string, you may run into issues when downloading file data because the browser thinks it should be a .txt file. If you instead set the content type to be "application/json", it will download just fine without a warning. Like so: "data:application/json;charset=utf-8"

Chrome warned me on MacOS whenever I wanted to download this file with a .json extension that had a content type of text/plain.
comment-27618:
Hi Radu, I just finished the first part of the course. Great so far, thank you. You asked if there was a better way to handle the download anchor click. I'd like to suggest the following:

const element = document.createElement("a");
element.setAttribute(
"href",
"data:text/plain;charset=utf-8," +
encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(data))
);

const fileName = data.session + ".json";
element.setAttribute("download", fileName);
element.click();

There shouldn't be any need to actually inject the anchor into the document. You can simply create the element and invoke the click directly in memory. Hope this helps :)

comment-27830:
I was following allong with the Javascript segment and ran into a problem where even after "this.paths" was consistent throughout the sketchpad, there was a problem with 'this.paths.push' still not being defined. As it turned out, it was chicken and egg problem with the array definition not have a valid array entry value, and thus being considered empty, and therefore, undefined. I was able to resolve this issue this this code:

<<< #addEventListeners(){
this.canvas.onmousedown = (evt) => {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath = [mouse]; // Start a new path with the starting point
this.isDrawing = true;
};

this.canvas.onmousemove = (evt) => {
if (this.isDrawing) {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath.push(mouse); // Add points to the current path
this.#redraw();
}
};

this.canvas.onmouseup = () => {
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
this.paths.push(this.currentPath); // Save the completed path
}
this.currentPath = null; // Reset the current path
this.isDrawing = false;
};
}


#redraw(){
this.ctx.clearRect(0, 0, this.canvas.width, this.canvas.height);
draw.paths(this.ctx, this.paths);
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
draw.path(this.ctx, this.currentPath); // Draw the currently active path
}
}>>>

comment-27851:
It happened to me that when I touched the screen and dragged my finger, the whole screen and the canvas were dragged together (28 min.).

I saw that this is the default behavior. So I just added a "preventDefault();" to functions associated with events.

Code:
this.canvas.ontouchstart = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousedown(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchmove = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousemove(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchend = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
this.canvas.onmouseup();
}

comment-27875:
Just as a quick aside in the beginning part, if you set the content type to "text/plain" in the data string, you may run into issues when downloading file data because the browser thinks it should be a .txt file. If you instead set the content type to be "application/json", it will download just fine without a warning. Like so: "data:application/json;charset=utf-8"

Chrome warned me on MacOS whenever I wanted to download this file with a .json extension that had a content type of text/plain.
comment-27876:
Hi Radu, I just finished the first part of the course. Great so far, thank you. You asked if there was a better way to handle the download anchor click. I'd like to suggest the following:

const element = document.createElement("a");
element.setAttribute(
"href",
"data:text/plain;charset=utf-8," +
encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(data))
);

const fileName = data.session + ".json";
element.setAttribute("download", fileName);
element.click();

There shouldn't be any need to actually inject the anchor into the document. You can simply create the element and invoke the click directly in memory. Hope this helps :)

comment-28005:
Hi Radu, I just finished the first part of the course. Great so far, thank you. You asked if there was a better way to handle the download anchor click. I'd like to suggest the following:

const element = document.createElement("a");
element.setAttribute(
"href",
"data:text/plain;charset=utf-8," +
encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(data))
);

const fileName = data.session + ".json";
element.setAttribute("download", fileName);
element.click();

There shouldn't be any need to actually inject the anchor into the document. You can simply create the element and invoke the click directly in memory. Hope this helps :)

comment-28595:
I was following allong with the Javascript segment and ran into a problem where even after "this.paths" was consistent throughout the sketchpad, there was a problem with 'this.paths.push' still not being defined. As it turned out, it was chicken and egg problem with the array definition not have a valid array entry value, and thus being considered empty, and therefore, undefined. I was able to resolve this issue this this code:

<<< #addEventListeners(){
this.canvas.onmousedown = (evt) => {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath = [mouse]; // Start a new path with the starting point
this.isDrawing = true;
};

this.canvas.onmousemove = (evt) => {
if (this.isDrawing) {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath.push(mouse); // Add points to the current path
this.#redraw();
}
};

this.canvas.onmouseup = () => {
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
this.paths.push(this.currentPath); // Save the completed path
}
this.currentPath = null; // Reset the current path
this.isDrawing = false;
};
}


#redraw(){
this.ctx.clearRect(0, 0, this.canvas.width, this.canvas.height);
draw.paths(this.ctx, this.paths);
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
draw.path(this.ctx, this.currentPath); // Draw the currently active path
}
}>>>

comment-28616:
It happened to me that when I touched the screen and dragged my finger, the whole screen and the canvas were dragged together (28 min.).

I saw that this is the default behavior. So I just added a "preventDefault();" to functions associated with events.

Code:
this.canvas.ontouchstart = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousedown(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchmove = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
const loc = e.touches[0];
this.canvas.onmousemove(loc);
}

this.canvas.ontouchend = (and) => {
e.preventDefault();
this.canvas.onmouseup();
}

comment-28640:
Just as a quick aside in the beginning part, if you set the content type to "text/plain" in the data string, you may run into issues when downloading file data because the browser thinks it should be a .txt file. If you instead set the content type to be "application/json", it will download just fine without a warning. Like so: "data:application/json;charset=utf-8"

Chrome warned me on MacOS whenever I wanted to download this file with a .json extension that had a content type of text/plain.
comment-28641:
Hi Radu, I just finished the first part of the course. Great so far, thank you. You asked if there was a better way to handle the download anchor click. I'd like to suggest the following:

const element = document.createElement("a");
element.setAttribute(
"href",
"data:text/plain;charset=utf-8," +
encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(data))
);

const fileName = data.session + ".json";
element.setAttribute("download", fileName);
element.click();

There shouldn't be any need to actually inject the anchor into the document. You can simply create the element and invoke the click directly in memory. Hope this helps :)

this.canvas.onmousedown = (evt) => {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath = [mouse]; // Start a new path with the starting point
this.isDrawing = true;
};

this.canvas.onmousemove = (evt) => {
if (this.isDrawing) {
const mouse = this.#getMouse(evt);
this.currentPath.push(mouse); // Add points to the current path
this.#redraw();
}
};

this.canvas.onmouseup = () => {
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
this.paths.push(this.currentPath); // Save the completed path
}
this.currentPath = null; // Reset the current path
this.isDrawing = false;
};
}


#redraw(){
this.ctx.clearRect(0, 0, this.canvas.width, this.canvas.height);
draw.paths(this.ctx, this.paths);
if (this.currentPath && this.currentPath.length) {
draw.path(this.ctx, this.currentPath); // Draw the currently active path
}
}>>>
